The Funklet

Clyde Stubblefield

Mother Popcorn

James Brown

1969

    @BPM

Most funky field trips makes a stop at this landmark beat.

Clyde started a new type of groove by playing quarter notes on the hi-hat. It gives the groove a jerky, all-broke-up feel.

This innovation wasn’t a highly concious decision; Clyde just went in the studio and started up a groove.

Because of the quarters on the hat, the kick and snare part sound totally fresh, even though it is similar to some past Stubblefield grooves.

It’s fun to ballpark the dates of funk tracks based on hi-hat parts. Invite over some friends, order some pizza and try it sometime.
